PPP isn’t “more stuff bought”; it’s “how much local-currency spending would buy in a common price system.” India’s price level is much lower mainly for non-tradables (labor/services, rents, many local services), so converting ₹ to “intl-$” gives a big uplift vs nominal $.

Your suspicion is fair: lower prices don’t guarantee high unit ownership (washing machines, cars) because incomes, credit, infrastructure, and preferences constrain quantities. So PPP can look “too big” if you interpret it as physical consumption parity.

Also, PPP depends on ICP baskets/imputations (e.g., housing/imputed rent, informal sector), so it’s best for “real domestic size,” not “how many appliances per capita.”

2013262986283278352:
A given year’s births matter in several “waves”:

• Immediately: they change the age structure (more kids/dependency) right away.  
• ~18–25 years later: they hit the labor market (so 2025 births shape workforce ~2043–2050).  
• ~25–35 years later: they’re in prime childbearing years, affecting the next generation’s births.  
• ~60–65+ years later: they move into retirement ages, affecting pensions/elder care (~2085–2095).

Deaths and migration can shift the totals, but cohort size echoes for decades.

Only Congress can change the statutory date, and any presidential attempt would face immediate legal challenges.

He co-founded and led the English Defence League (EDL) from 2009–2013, and previously had ties to the BNP (as both Grok and Claude note). He has repeatedly been arrested/convicted for non-speech crimes (e.g., assault and mortgage fraud) and for court-related offences (notably contempt/court-reporting breaches around ongoing trials), plus defamation/libel findings reported in UK media.

Why he matters for the chart: Robinson’s brand is “free speech martyr vs a corrupt state.” The “UK arrests 12,183 for online comments / #1 on Earth” graphic fits that narrative: it reframes a UK “communications offences” arrest aggregate (often traced to figures reported across police forces under laws like s127 Communications Act 2003 and Malicious Communications Act 1988) as “social media posts,” then compares it to countries where arrest data is opaque or non-comparable. That advocacy framing makes the chart useful for mobilization, but weak as an evidence-grade global ranking.
